{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3131445,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-21T20:21:04.574Z","cooked":"

Do Andymark or Vex clock their sprockets so the teeth line up with the mounting holes?

Likewise the hubs…

We have an application where we need to sprockets with the teeth in the same orientation.

According to the layout prints on the website, it looks like the newer plate and symmetrical sprockets from AndyMark call out having their bores and mounting holes timed to their teeth.

image1396×946 171 KB

Yes, the plate sprockets are also indexed.

As mentioned above, all REV ION sprockets and gears are clocked hex to teeth, or maxspline to teeth.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2023-01-21T21:08:28.269Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":443,"readers_count":442,"score":183.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":424230,"topic_slug":"plate-sprockets-are-any-clocked-so-the-teeth-line-up","display_username":"REV Robotics Co-founder & CEO","primary_group_name":"REV","flair_name":"REV","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/d/b/db93216ec14c273ae2ca04aa396186c0461d0620.png","flair_bg_color":"F05A28","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":55,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"REV Robotics","title_is_group":false,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":511,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/plate-sprockets-are-any-clocked-so-the-teeth-line-up/424230/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3131480,"name":"Stewart Riley","username":"Strategic","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/strategic/{size}/10157_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-21T21:15:36.260Z","cooked":"

Well, I have two 64t Rev Ion sprockets sitting on my desk right now and I can tell you that they are identical, so yes, they are clocked. In more general terms, any two sprockets of the same size from the same manufacturer are almost certain to be identical since they’re manufactured by milling machines from the same CAD file. That means that teeth and mounting holes will line up perfectly between sprockets as long as you have them in the same orientation (i.e., with some tooth configurations you may have to rotate them to get the teeth and the mounting holes to line up between sprockets, but they will in at least one orientation to each other.)

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2023-01-21T21:18:07.670Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":450,"readers_count":449,"score":95.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":424230,"topic_slug":"plate-sprockets-are-any-clocked-so-the-teeth-line-up","display_username":"Stewart Riley","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":34339,"username":"nhos","name":"Alex S","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nhos/{size}/127310_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32783,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"I plan, therefore I am"},"post_url":"/t/plate-sprockets-are-any-clocked-so-the-teeth-line-up/424230/6","custom_user_title":"I plan, therefore I am","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3131636,"name":"Cory","username":"Cory","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cory/{size}/312_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-22T00:49:32.797Z","cooked":"

Sprockets are often hobbed, not milled, which means a second op to add holes. Unless there’s a fixture used to align, any of those secondary operations will not be clocked.

In the absence of a drawing indicating clocking or a vendor stating their products are clocked, it’s definitely safest to assume they are not.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2023-01-22T00:49:32.797Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":416,"readers_count":415,"score":273.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":424230,"topic_slug":"plate-sprockets-are-any-clocked-so-the-teeth-line-up","display_username":"Cory","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":32783,"username":"Strategic","name":"Stewart Riley","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/strategic/{size}/10157_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":14}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":1037,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/plate-sprockets-are-any-clocked-so-the-teeth-line-up/424230/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":10},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":14,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3131661,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-22T01:37:49.471Z","cooked":"

That’s good to know. If someone had asked me i would have guessed they were stamped.

I think it’s a mix of both depending on size/material/qty

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2023-01-22T01:44:18.077Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":371,"readers_count":370,"score":114.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":424230,"topic_slug":"plate-sprockets-are-any-clocked-so-the-teeth-line-up","display_username":"Cory","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":7841,"username":"Tom_Line","name":"Tom Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":1037,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/plate-sprockets-are-any-clocked-so-the-teeth-line-up/424230/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3137935,"name":"NathanNFM","username":"NathanNFM","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nathannfm/{size}/181060_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-01T21:34:50.179Z","cooked":"
mooose:

According to the layout prints on the website, it looks like the newer plate and symmetrical sprockets from AndyMark call out having their bores and mounting holes timed to their teeth.

We had checked for this when they were received, but apparently did not examine a large enough sample size, and unfortunately it looks like this year our sprockets will not necessarily be timed. We have added a note to the web pages.
If you have already ordered and require this timing please drop us a line at support@andymark.com. Be sure to include your order number and the quantity that you need to match and I will hand select replacements for you. Sorry for the inconvenience.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2023-02-01T21:36:25.650Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":230,"readers_count":229,"score":116.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":424230,"topic_slug":"plate-sprockets-are-any-clocked-so-the-teeth-line-up","display_username":"NathanNFM","primary_group_name":"AndyMark","flair_name":"AndyMark","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/7/2/72db24f824a25ae17c6413b3d02a345e47f060a9.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":59,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14566,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"AndyMark Senior Mechanical Engineer"},"post_url":"/t/plate-sprockets-are-any-clocked-so-the-teeth-line-up/424230/10","custom_user_title":"AndyMark Senior Mechanical Engineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"cry","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3137951,"name":"Troy Dietz","username":"troy_dietz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/troy_dietz/{size}/135768_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-01T22:01:59.098Z","cooked":"

Depending on the specific design, mis-timed sprockets can be beneficial. With parallel chain runs connecting the same shafts you can force a bit of preload on the chain and reduce backlash, especially helpful on arms that can reach “behind” the normal configuration.

That’s also tricky to get right the first time and I’d take Nathan up on the offer. Something to try out for offseason practice; sometimes it shows up intentionally in the “real world”: most engines with timing chains use a similar trick for fine adjustments.

We managed to get two 2 plate sprockets and 2 hex sprockets that were close but not exactly timed to line up this way.

This is essentially how anti-backlash gears work. They are a thing you can buy.

I assume people are asking this question because they are running two chains up to an arm joint. In this situation where not much rotation is needed I would put one of those turnbuckle chain tighteners on one of the chains to tighten it. I would then put two of them on the other chain which should give enough adjustment to get it timed right.
I’ve never done this, but it seems like it would work.
